titleStmt.title: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 176/97

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 176/97

foliation.p: Written in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf.

The manuscript opens and ends with two modern paper flyleaves. For the purposes of producing a functional electronic catalogue record for the volume as part of the Curious Cures project, these leaves have been assigned page numbers in square brackets: pp. [i]-[ii], [ii]-[iv], [v]-[vi], and [vii]-[viii].

collation.formula: 124-6 (1st and 12th leaves replaced; 15th-19th leaves missing, and 1 other leaf missing in the second half of the quire, perhaps the 22nd leaf) | 2-420 520-1 (1st leaf replaced; 1 leaf cancelled in the second half of the quire) 620-3 (1st, 9th, 10th leave missing)

signatures.p: Quire numbers written in pencil in the right-hand lower corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th-century reverse brown calfskin with panel design (blind-stamped frames with floral motifs at the cornes of the central frame).

provenance.p: Robert Matthius [Matthews] (fl. 16th century) Matthius [Matthews], Robert, fl. 16th century: inscribed his first name in the lower margin of p. 1 ('Robert'); his ownership inscription in the lower margin of p. 11 ('Robert Matthius his Booke witnes Semuel [sic: Samuel] Salt'); and his full name in a jordan on p. 101 ('Robert Matthius').
William Moore (1590-1659) Moore, William, 1590-1659, BA, MA, fellow of and lecturer in rhetoric at Gonville and Caius College, and librarian of Cambridge University Library.

history.acquisition: Given or bequeathed by William Moore to Gonville and Caius College in 1659: its armorial bookplate pasted on the inside of the upper cover, inscribed with the classmark numbers '176' and '97'; number 1075 in the catalogue of the College's manuscripts in Edward Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697) and this number also inscribed on the inside of the upper cover; also recorded as no. 176 in the catalogue of J.J. Smith, A Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Deighton and Macmillan, 1849).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, 2 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1908) and Kari Anne Rand Schmidt, Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Brewer, 2001).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 176/97, pp. 1-36

msItem.title: Propositum est [English translation of Latin treatise on phlebotomy]
msItem.author: Henry of Winchester
msItem.incipit: 1 [T]he purpos forsoth of þis present besynes yt ys for to tret shortly in which maner sekenes flebotomie ys competent and of which veynis þerfor it is to wyt that some minsion is made or done by metacentesyn id est evyn drawyng some by antepasyn ys sayd to be done when þe blode ys drawyn on þe same parte in which ys the sekenes
msItem.explicit: 11 Wherefore sekirnesse is more for to slit þe veynez after lengþe wiþ an instrument as warkyfe as haþe french men and oþire also and namely þo þat han streyte veynez and of fleubotomye þese þyngis sufisyn aftir maistre henricus wyntonyensis amen

listBibl.bibl: For another copy, see Rand Schmidt (2001), pp. 41-42
Voigts and McVaugh (1984), pp. 37-53 (odd pages only) [edition from this MS]

msItem.title: Arithemetical puzzle (card trick)
msItem.incipit: 12 salue: duke / erle / baron; iii: noble / half noble / xxd; 1 / 2 / 3: d / e / b / a / e / i
msItem.explicit: 12 maris: duke / baron / erle; ii: half noble / noble / xxd; 1 / 2 / 3: a / e / i
msItem.note: Transcribed in full (with some errors) by M.R. James.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Rand Schmidt (2001), p. 42

msItem.title: Chaucer's 'Complaynt to his Empty Purse'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: 12 Now purse that be to me my lyvys light / And saveour as in this worde downe here
msItem.explicit: 12 And you that may all my mys amend / Haue mynde opon my supplicacioun

listBibl.bibl: Pace, 'The Text of Chaucer's Purse' (1948), pp. 117-18

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 12 Vnde superbimus, quid ego, quid tu, nisi limus / Limus homo primus, sortem mutare nequimus
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Four Distichs
msItem.incipit: 13 Munus fit iudex fructus est mercator in vrbe / Nec lex est diris, nec timor pueris - primus
msItem.explicit: 13 Prudentes ceci, cognati degeneres sunt / Mortuus ignotus, nullus amicus amat - 4

msItem.title: Carmen de algorismo, excerpt of [English translation]
msItem.author: Alexander de Villa Dei
msItem.incipit: 13 Verses of þe .7. spices of algrym / septem sunt partes non plures istius artis
msItem.explicit: 13 Duplicacioun / Multiplicacioun / Diuisioun / Radix extraxcioun: on þe lefte hand

listBibl.bibl: For a descripton of this copy, see Rand Schmidt (2001), p. 119

msItem.title: List of Latin philosophical terms and their English equivalents
msItem.incipit: 13 Genus - kynde of generalte / Species - spice or specialte / Differencia - difference / Proprium - propyirte / Accidense - accidente
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: De Kalendario
msItem.incipit: 13 Þese ar termes of þe newe kalendere verus locus solus quantitas diei artific[...]
msItem.explicit: 14 quantitas temporis a mereidie ad noctis obscurum is fro mydday to derke nyȝte
msItem.note: The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: List of the qualities and properties of the twelve houses
msItem.rubric: 14 Tripliciteis qualites et propretes of .12. houses
msItem.incipit: 14 [A]tiractife [?] : Aries / Leo / Sagittarius: hote and drie colric fiere orientale or est
msItem.explicit: 14 Taurus / Cancer / Virgo / Scorpio / Capricornus / Pisses : ffemynyng syngnes
msItem.note: The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: List of planets and zodiacal signs
msItem.rubric: 14 House of planetes bi þe .12. sygnes
msItem.incipit: 14 Leo - house of þe sonne
msItem.explicit: 14 Gemini - house of mercurij

msItem.title: List of opposite zodiacal signs
msItem.incipit: 14 Aries - Libra
msItem.explicit: 14 Cancer - Capricornus
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Figure of the twelve astrological houses
msItem.rubric: 15 A figure in þe 12 house in þe firmament
msItem.incipit: 15 1 ascendent lyne
msItem.explicit: 15 12 enuey ys dispair

msItem.title: List of terms for the twelve astrological houses
msItem.incipit: 15 1 viuere 2 rem 3 fratres
msItem.explicit: 15 10 iudicium 11 spes 12 i[...]cicie
msItem.note: The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: Mnemonic for the twelve astrological houses
msItem.incipit: 15 1 ascendyng lif 2 substance 3 breþren
msItem.explicit: 15 10 þe dyngnyte 11 of frendis and 12 enuies eke

msItem.title: List of English terms with synonyms for the parts of an astrolabe
msItem.rubric: 15 Þe termes of þe astirlabie of astronomie
msItem.incipit: 16 The ryng þe turett þe modire þe plate of climate
msItem.explicit: 16 þe arch þe corde recte or ryȝte þe corde verse or turned

msItem.title: List of res naturales, res non naturales and res contra naturales
msItem.incipit: 16 Þe .7. natural þyngis: elementis commixtions or complexiounus compositions or humeruus membres vertues operaciouns sperites
msItem.explicit: 16 .3. þyngis agayn nature: sekenesse causes and accidentis
msItem.note: According to Voigts and McVaugh (p. 24) the list corresponds to the concepts and doctrines introduced in Galen's Tegni as explained in the Isagoge by Hunain ibn Ishaq [Johannitius].

msItem.title: Questions and answeres which expound on the list res natures, res non naturales and res contra naturales
msItem.incipit: 16 Natural þyngis ordeyneth or makyþ a bodi as elementis humours etcaetera
msItem.explicit: 19 wherefor seiþ seneca he þat growth vp withine and þat quekenyþ me[...] sleþ me[...] þe example of þis is schewid in a lampe and oyle
msItem.note: Full transcription.
The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: Note on types of reference
msItem.incipit: 20 [...] Remoratiue of þynge passide / Demonstratiue of þyng present / Pronosticatiue of þyng þat is to come
msItem.note: Full transcription.
The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: Tract on humours and diseases
msItem.incipit: 20 Materiale / fformale / Efficient / ffinale - cause
msItem.explicit: 20 Of melancolie is þat some porsioun of it be sent to diuerse membres and þat melancolius membris as bonys senowys and cartilage be nurschid wiþ
msItem.note: The text is partially illegible due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: Tract on apostemes
msItem.incipit: 20 What is a posteme a gretnesse or inflacion id est boylyng þat þe membris suffren of superflue humours
msItem.explicit: 20 and sych oþer inwarde causes ben .6. after Auicen þat is .4 humours and quosite \watri and vencosite |wyndenesse/
msItem.note: The tract refers to Avicenna.

msItem.title: Note on types of medicines
msItem.incipit: 20 .3. þyngis medicinale: Alteratiues / Euacuatiues / Confortatiues
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: List classifying parts of the body according to humours
msItem.incipit: 20 Ordere of hote membris: 1 Sperite and þe hert 2 Blode 3 Lyuere
msItem.explicit: 21 hert / felyng senowis / skyn

msItem.title: List of the number of bones, veins and teeth in the human body and the number of bones in the bodies of animals
msItem.incipit: 21 Nota in Corpore humano de ossibus ijC et xl[...
msItem.explicit: 21 Cete vj Ml vC lv
msItem.note: The list enumerates the bones of 'Cepes', dogs, horses, (?) 'homo', deer, crows, eagles, and whales. Added by a different hand in the 16th century.

msItem.title: A pure balade of love [the glamour of a knight errant] [excerpt from Book IV of John Gower's Confessio Amantis]
msItem.author: John Gower
msItem.rubric: 23 A pure balade of love [attributed title by a later hand]
msItem.incipit: 23 Knyȝte in travayle for to serve / Wherof the may thanke deserve
msItem.explicit: 23 Vaillant viallant Lo where he goith / And then he gyvith hym gold and cloth

msItem.title: Chaucer’s 'Complaynt to his Empty Purse'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 23 A L Nother balade [attributed title by a later hand]
msItem.incipit: 23 To you my purce and non other wyȝt / Complayne I for you by my lady dere
msItem.explicit: 23 Quene of comfort and of all company / Be hevy agayne or els most I dye

listBibl.bibl: Pace, 'The Text of Chaucer’s Purse' (1948), pp. 117-18

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Three recipes added by a later (16th-century) hand, including to unguents and a recipe for eye ailments.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 33 et detur in media nocte tepidum etcaetera
msItem.note: Copied in a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: List of four seasons with signs of the Zodiac and monts
msItem.incipit: 35 Hyem: Capricornus / Aquarius / Pisses - Januarius / Decembre / Februarius
msItem.explicit: 35 Autumpnus: Libra / Scorpio / Sagitarius - Novembre / Octobre / Septembre

msItem.title: List of veins in the human body
msItem.incipit: 35 In templis: doloribus aurium valent - et visum oculorum
msItem.explicit: 35 et dolori maxillarum pro dolor antiquo capitis pro stupore mentis

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: A medical recipe in a later (16th-century) hand with two crossed out drafts written above it; the same hand added medical recipes to p. 24.

support.material: Paper, folded in quarto with two watermarks: scales and a mountain with a cross.

list.item: Quire 124-6 (pp. 1-36: 1st and 12th leaves replaced; 15th-19th leaves missing, and 1 other leaf missing in the second half of the quire, perhaps the 22nd leaf)

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. About 32 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: A late 15th- or early 16th-century hand has replaced text for a missing leaf on pp. 1-2 in a Secretary script; the same hand has copied text to replace a missing leaf in the manuscript's second part on pp. 157-158
A single hand has copied medical texts on pp. 3-11, 13-21, 33-34 in a cursive Anglicana script.
One or two hands have copied verse texts on pp. 12-13, 23 in a Secretary script.
One hand has added medical texts to p. 35 in a script with both Secretary and Anglicana features.
A later (16th-century) hand has added Latin medical recipes to pp. 24 and 35 in a Secretary script.

decoNote.p: An astrological chart drawn in black in on p. 15.
Underlining in red ink on pp. 12-13 and 23

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 176/97, pp. 37-228

msItem.title: Medical compilation
msItem.rubric: 37 Prologus istius tractatus secundum linguam maternam
msItem.incipit: 37 As salamon sayth in þe firste boke of of [sic] his prouerbis firste chapitre sayth þus initium sapientie est timor domini bygynnynge of wisdom ys þe dred of god and as aristole [sic] sayth in þe þride capitre of ethikis where he sayt þus omnium exspediendorum principium est dei sapientia þe bygynnyng of eueri þynge ys þe wysdom of god
msItem.explicit: 228 tak eyschell y brent filipo'-
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly in chapter 45, which, according to the rubric, is the last. The compiler identifies himself as 'Aystyn' and states that he produces his work for his friend 'Thomas Plawdon'. Thomas Plouden (d. 1413) was a London citizen and barber-surgeon of the parish of All Hallows the Great A treatise on apostemes in Peterhouse 118, ff. 55v-65r, has also been translated for him.

The work compiles relies on many medical works, including (p. 120) the 'booke of feuerys of galterus' (i.e. Walter of Agilon [Galterius Agilus]), , and the ((p. 133) 'tretis of rasis [?]albulumnninon' (i.e. Abū Bakr Muḥammad ibn Zakariyyāʾ al-Rāzī [Rhazes]).

listBibl.bibl: For other texts, see Rand Schmidt (2001), p. 45

msItem.title: Liber Uricrisiarum
msItem.author: Henry Daniel
msItem.rubric: 65 þe fifth chapitre ys what ys an vryne and were of sayd quid est vrina et vnde dicatur
msItem.incipit: 65 [F]or to knowe what ys an vryn I say as þe comente on gylis sayt in his firste Boke of vrynes þe firste chapitre þus he sayt þere þat vryne is as meche to say in english as one in þe raynes þat ys to mene vryne ys an onyng and a gaderyng to gederis in þe lendys ffor þe reynes ys frenche þe wiche ys þe lendys in englische and why it ys sayde one in þe reynes for þere it ys kyndely causyd and formed
msItem.explicit: 120 þe ferþe condicioun of ypostasis ys tyme þat ys to say ȝif ypostasis abyde many dayes or elles day be day liche a pynappul white clere and þynne and hool to gedris it ys þanne þe beste signe þat may be of helpe ffor it signifieþ þat þe kynde nature is of myȝt to worche and to ouercome þe vnkynde maledyes of þe body
msItem.finalRubric: 120 Now it is endyd þe vrinys and hir colours with hir contentes and hir signifcacioun
msItem.note: The shorter version of Henry Daniel's LIber Uricrisiarum, illustrated with jordans, and incorporated into a large medical compendium (pp. 65-120).

listBibl.bibl: For other texts, see Rand Schmidt (2001), p. 45
'The Seventeen-Chapter Abridgement', in The Henry Daniel Project (https://henrydaniel.utoronto.ca/urines/manuscripts/list/) [accessed 24 February 2023]

support.material: Paper, folded in quarto with different watermarks: scales, a dragon (wyvern) and a (?) shield.

list.item: Quire 520-1 (pp. 157-194: 1st leaf replaced; 1 leaf cancelled in the second half of the quire)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in frames of red ink in the right-hand lower margin of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. 30-31 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied almost entirely by a single scribe in a cursive Anglicana script.

A late 15th- or early 16th-century hand has replaced text for a missing leaf on pp. 157-158 in a Secretary script; the same hand has copied text to replace a missing leaf in the manuscript's first part on pp. 1-2.

decoNote.p: Drawings of jordans on pp. 81-103. Initially, the jorands have been coloured in, but they are left unfinished (only outlined in brown ink) after from p. 88 onwards.
One large (3-line) dark grey initial 'O' with a human face drawn inside it with black in on p. 85; perhaps added at a later stage.
Headers rubricated in red ink throughout.
Small (1 line) capitals occasionally highlighted with red ink.
Paraphs in red ink when used in regular text and in black ink when used in rubricated text.
Underlining and strikethroughs in red ink.
Guide letters in blank spaces left for large coloured initials throughout.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
